perturbation.changed_text:
The parties mutually covenant that they will keep each other's confidential information in strict confidence, and will use only for the purpose of this Agreement, shall not use or permit others to use the confidential information or disclose such to any third parties except the following event:

  7.2.1 Upon the written consent of the other party;
perturbation.explanation: Removing clauses 7.2.2 and 7.2.3 weakens confidentiality obligations. Chinese law provides specific exceptions to confidentiality, such as mandatory disclosures to government agencies. Removing these exceptions creates a legal contradiction, as the contract could be interpreted as forbidding legally required disclosures. The confidentiality is so strict that if the laws of PRC mandates an entity to reveal such information, it cannot. This is not permissable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law; PRC Cybersecurity Law

perturbation.original_text:
In the event of Force Majeure, the affected party shall notify the other party in respect of the nature, incurring date, anticipated lasting time and related details as fastest as reasonably possible and the degree of such event hindering the performance of its obligations of the notifying party hereunder.

  11.7.2 During the consecutive period of the Force Majeure, the affected party shall regularly and timely keep the other party informed of the current status of the Force Majeure, in the event that the Force Majeure ends, it shall notify the other party in writing timely and continue to perform the obligations hereunder.

  11.7.3 The party affected by the Force Majeure may temporarily suspend the performance hereunder until the influence of the Force Majeure is removed after it performs its obligations pursuant to Item 1 and 2 of this Article and need not to bear any breach liabilities; however, it shall use best efforts to conquer such event and minimize its adverse influence.
perturbation.changed_text:
In the event of Force Majeure, the affected party may suspend the performance hereunder until the influence of the Force Majeure is removed. 

  11.7.3 The party affected by the Force Majeure need not bear any breach liabilities.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement for the affected party to notify the other party about the Force Majeure event (nature, date, duration, etc.) and regularly update them on its status creates a **legal contradiction**. Under PRC Contract Law, parties have a duty to mitigate losses and inform the other party of events that may affect contract performance. Removing these notification requirements limits the ability of the unaffected party to take mitigating actions, potentially leading to greater losses. The initial text gives a more comprehensive description of the process of informing the parties regarding the Force Majeure, whereas in the modified text, the process of informing is removed and thus can create more losses for a party.

perturbation.original_text:
Any dispute arising from the construction and enforcement of this Agreement shall be settled through friendly consultation ormediation by a neutral third party first.

  10.2.2 If the dispute fails to be resolved within thirty (30) days by such method set forth above, either party shall submit to the court inthe location of Party B.
perturbation.changed_text: Any dispute arising from the construction and enforcement of this Agreement shall be submitted to the court in the location of Party B.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause about 'friendly consultation or mediation by a neutral third party first' before resorting to court proceedings creates a **legal contradiction** with common commercial practice and principles of good faith negotiation recognized under PRC law. Chinese courts often encourage or require mediation before formal litigation. Eliminating the pre-litigation negotiation step can be seen as a failure to act in good faith and could potentially impact the enforceability of the agreement. The text removes the consultation or meditation stage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Civil Procedure Law; General Principles of Civil Law
